title: Liverpool's Melwood move is the latest step in Jurgen Klopp's behind-the-scenes revolution for the club
text:
Samuel L Jackson reveals when he became a Liverpool fan Share this video Watch Next 
The Dutchman oversees the weekly ‘Futures Group’ at Melwood which features the cream of the Academy crop but there are still logistical issues. 
Klopp wants to be closer to the Academy’s 170 youngsters looking to make the grade and the staff working to help them. He admitted back in October that he hadn’t watched the under-18s live at Kirkby since his second day in the job 12 months earlier. 
“Last season we had absolutely no time,” Klopp said. “It’s one of the reasons why we really think about possibly all coming together here. It would be easier. You wouldn’t need to drive between two different places.” 
Klopp knows it would also be a source of inspiration for kids walking out to train and seeing the likes of Philippe Coutinho and Roberto Firmino working nearby. 
The German coach has felt constrained by a lack of space at Melwood where the indoor facility is small and dated. There’s also a shortage of meeting rooms and offices. 
There will be no such issues at Kirkby with the purchase of playing fields from Knowsley Metropolitan Borough Council set to boost the size of the site to 60 acres. Klopp is frustrated by the five-mile gap between Melwood and the Liverpool academy (Photo: Liverpool FC) Kirkby would also offer the first-team a more secluded base (Photo: Liverpool FC) Read More Philippe Coutinho shares incredibly cute moment with daughter Maria as Liverpool star enjoys two-week break 
Klopp was initially concerned about how exposed the Academy is to the elements and in particular how the wind would affect his training sessions. 
But Liverpool believe they have solved the problem by seeking advice from experts on how best to combat the issue with new landscaping and the planting of dozens of trees. 
Another attraction in moving to Kirkby is how secluded it is. That should help prevent team information from leaking out. Currently, fans use bins, cars or ladders to look over the walls at Melwood and watch training. 
Leaving Melwood is a big step for Liverpool considering it has been home since the 1950s. It was Bill Shankly who transformed the place in the 1960s and then Gerard Houllier brought it into the 21st century when he oversaw a major redevelopment in 2001. 
Three years earlier the new Academy in Kirkby opened its doors after the decision was taken to have a dedicated youth development base elsewhere. Read More Daniel Sturridge set to return to training after being sent home from Liverpool's La Manga trip 
Former boss Brendan Rodgers was also keen on the idea of amalgamating Melwood and Kirkby with chief executive Ian Ayre telling the ECHO back in 2013 that a feasibility study had been commissioned on the subject. 
“Brendan has said recently he wishes he could see more of the Academy than he does and that being between two sites isn’t ideal,” Ayre said. 
“It is something we have looked at in the past but for every decision like that it comes back to finding the right economic model. There is definitely more value in having everyone together.” 
With owners Fenway Sports Group vowing to back Klopp’s vision, it’s now set to become a reality. If everything goes to plan Klopp will be taking training in sparkling new surroundings in July 2019. poll loading Will Liverpool win the title with Klopp? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
